entry.title: AI-driven, Joule-enabled Warehouse Resource & Operations Management for SAP EWM on S/4 HANA 2023
entry.content:
It is a topic in every warehouse: Supervisors and Warehouse Operations Managers would like to see their planned workload for the day and see in real-time whether shipping times will be met. If shipping times are in jeopardy, the warehouse system is then expected to evaluate if an optimized resource allocation could pro-actively solve any potential delays. When a more optimal usage of the available resources is found, resources should automatically be directed to the critical areas. Being able to take action proactively is of the essence, because we do not want to only take action when we are already in delay.

The following is an example of an AI-driven, Joule enabled Application that can accomplish the above outlined requirements and activities supported by AI. The Application leverages the embedded AI in the EWM Private Cloud Edition S/4 HANA 2023 FPS03 release and the Joule Studio available in SAP Build.

 

 

The Architecture of the Application looks as follows:

 

AI-based Warehouse Workload Visibility

In the current version of the Application, the expected workloads of picking and packing operations are calculated leveraging the embedded AI capabilities in SAP EWM, which are then displayed in the UI5 Application (see in the example below):

It is also clearly visible in which Activity Area the workload is currently exceeding the planned Resource capacity.

The Application then further allows a manual simulation of adding or removing Resources to evaluate the impact in a given activity area. 

The fully "automatic rebalancing" function evaluates whether it is possible to optimize the resource allocation to the different areas, considering the allowed resource types in an Activity Area.

If an optimized resource allocation is possible, the warehouse operations manager, can accept these changes and the resources will be reassigned in the EWM system so that they will receive workload to execute from the new area.

Joule-enabled with custom EWM Joule Skills

Further more the current version of the Application provides Joule support for Warehouse Operations Management with the following Joule Skills:

- Joule Skill 1: Current Workload Analysis: Provide a comprehensive analysis of the current workload associated with picking and packing operations, considering the current resource allocation across different warehouse areas, as well as dependent scheduling of packing activities.
- Joule Skill 2: Provide Optimized Resource Allocation: Simulate an optimal workforce allocation strategy to mitigate bottlenecks and criticalities within the warehouse operations, to avoid shipping delays.
- Joule Skill 3: Accept Optimized Resource Allocation: Accept the optimization results and reassign the resources in EWM to the new areas.   

Coming soon an AI Agent will be introduce that autonomously orchestrates workforce allocation (monitored by the supervisor).

For more Information on this Application & AI functionality please contact SAP Services (EWMServices@sap.com).

The handling of transportation forms like Waybill, CMR and Subcontracting Form is based on Output Management with Adobe Forms. You cannot change SAP-delivered standard forms directly.

However, you can create a copy of the standard form template in the maintain Form Templates app, enhance it with additional fields or make layout changes using Adobe LiveCycle Designer. Then assign your custom form to the relevant output type through the Output Parameter Determination.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Holiday Readiness – Secure Your Backoffice Before Peak Season
entry.content:
As part of the SAP Holiday Season Readiness Program, we’re helping you prepare for record-breaking traffic and sales. One critical step: protect your Backoffice and HAC from public exposure.

 

Why It Matters

Your Backoffice powers essential operations behind the scenes, non-customer-facing operations that supports crucial administrative and operational functions to ensure an e-commerce business runs smoothly, allowing businesses to scale.

Your Backoffice/HAC has administrative privileges in your e-commerce data and should not strictly be accessible publicly. It is vital to make sure that the environments are secure, to avoid a strong possibility of an attack leveraging them. If exposed to the internet, it becomes a high-value target for attackers—especially during the holiday rush.

Risks of Exposure

  • 🔓 Unauthorized Access - Attackers can discover and access internal systems without authentication barriers.
  • 🤖 Brute Force & Credential Stuffing Attacks - Login portals are targeted with automated password-guessing tools.
  • 🕵️‍ Sensitive Data Exposure - Internal dashboards or APIs may leak customer PII, business data, or system logs.
  • 💣 Malware & Ransomware Infection - Open endpoints can be used to deploy malicious payloads to internal systems.
  • ⬆️ Privilege Escalation - If attackers get in, they may gain administrative privileges and full control of the backend.
  • 📉 Reputational and Operational Impact - Downtime, data loss, and customer trust erosion can result from a breach.

How to Protect

  • Remove 0.0.0.0/0 (allow all) from your allow list.
  • Implement IP Filters and VPN for secure access.

📚 SAP Guidelines:

  • IP Filter Configuration
  • VPN Setup

Act now to secure your Backoffice before the holiday surge.

entry.title: Prevent Sensitive Data Exposure in URLs
entry.content:
High traffic means more transactions—and more risk. A common misconfiguration during integrations is sending PII data in the URL of a POST request instead of in the request body. This can lead to serious data leaks.

 

Why It’s Dangerous

URLs can be logged, cached, and exposed in browser history or analytics tools, making sensitive data vulnerable.

🔍Learn more: OWASP Guidelines

How to Fix It

  • Configure the POST request in a secured way. Always send PII in the body of the POST request, never in the URL.

📚 SAP Guidelines:

  • SAP CX Commerce Cloud Security Guide

Secure your integrations now to protect customer trust during peak season.

entry.title: Eliminate Default Password Risks
entry.content:
Default passwords are an open invitation for attackers and should not be in use in your environments. All default passwords involved should be changed immediately to make sure that your environments are safe and secure. With holiday traffic surging, the stakes are higher than ever.

 

What’s at Risk

  • 🔓 Unauthorized Access - Attackers can log in easily using well-known default credentials.
  • 💥 Website Defacement - Hackers may change content, inject malicious scripts, or vandalize the site.
  • 🛠 Privilege Escalation - Default credentials may allow full admin access.
  • 📉 Reputational Damage - Compromises can erode user trust and damage your brand.

What You Should Do

  • Change all default passwords immediately.
  • Regularly review and update credentials.

📚 SAP Guidelines:

  • Change Backoffice Password
  • Update Built-in User Passwords

Need help? Open a support ticket today.

It says

"The Etag handling feature is implemented on the A_SalesOrder node with the LastChangeDateTime property. If you want to use ETag handling for other entities (for example, A_SalesOrderItem), proceed as follows:

  1. Perform a GET operation to retrieve the content for the LastChangeDateTime property.

  2. Create a $batch request containing one changeset.

  3. As first operation of the changeset, include a PATCH A_SalesOrder with the LastChangeDateTime property. Provide the LastChangeDateTime content also in the request header in the If-Match field.

  4. As second operation of the changeset, include the desired payload (for example, POST A_SalesOrderItem or PATCH A_SalesOrderItem) with the relevant data"

entry.title: Re: e-Doc Submission Error from SD Module Due to Missing...
entry.content:
1. Ensure Posting Before Sending
  • Confirm that the export document is posted in SAP before triggering the “Send” action in the cockpit.
  • Posting ensures that the discharge date and other required fields are populated.
  1. Check for Missing Data
  • Use the error display feature in the cockpit:
    • Double-click the Logs/File column in the cockpit to open the details pane.
    • Review the application log, interface log, and last file for specific error messages.
  1. Correct and Resubmit
  • If the discharge date or other mandatory fields are missing:
    • Cancel the current eDocument.
    • Manually cancel the source document if needed.
    • Correct the data (e.g., populate the discharge date).
    • Resubmit the eDocument
  1. Customizing Settings
  • Ensure that the Document Compliance Framework is properly configured:
    • Maintain parameters in EDOGENCUST (e.g., NEW_SCREEN = X) to enable detailed error views.
    • Refer to SAP Note 3005076 for additional configuration guidance

entry.title: Re: SAP Business Data Cloud Series – Part 3: Customer-Managed Data Products
entry.content:
@MelCalucin : Please find the below answers:

  • In a typical medallion architecture, the layers serve different purposes:

    Bronze Data Layer: raw source data, ingested as-is. Silver Data Layer: cleansed and transformed data. Gold Data Layer: business-ready data enriched with semantics, associations, unions and joins.
    Depending on data quality from the source and business requirements, you may design 3 layers, 2 layers, or even just 1.

  • The exact approach depends on the use case. For example, a Sales Order CDS view already combines data from both Sales Header and Item views.

  • As a best practice, customers should leverage SAP-released CDS views first, extend them where needed, and only create custom CDS views when business requirements demand it. This is fully permissible under the clean core paradigm, as business requirements ultimately take priority.

Hope this helps, Jeet

entry.title: SAP MES - Add formula to work instruction?
entry.content:
Currently I have the following example system in place.

  • Part number 123 has an instruction to mill it to a thickness of 2in +/-.1in
  • Part Number 456 has an instruction to mill it to a thickness of 3in +/-.15in
  • Currently there are two work instructions one called Milling_123 where the instruction is fully written out as "Mill to 2in +/-.1in" and another instruction called Milling_456 where the instruction is written as "Mill to 3in +/-.15in"

Is it possible to add either a formula to a work instruction or some sort of parameterization so that we could have one instruction simply called "Milling" where it is written as something like

  • "Mill to _nominaldimension_ +/- _tolerance_" and those _xxx_ values are found by looking up values in the SQL database for each part number?
  • That way we only need one work instruction and we can make small clerical changes once while still keeping all of the important dimensions simply referenced from the database.
  • This sort of parameterization works for the formula function in data collection but I can't seem to find if it's possible to do it in work instructions.

entry.title: Re: How to Post Exchange Rate Differences to P&L Instead...
entry.content: @AlvaroFernandezMorales solution is to change the material's price control from Moving Average Price (V) to Standard Price (S) and then verify the account assignment for transaction keys PRD and KDM in the "Configure Automatic Account Determination" app (F1273).

entry.title: Re: How to Post Exchange Rate Differences to P&L Instead...
entry.content:
Hello @AlvaroFernandezMorales 

Thank you for your question.

The system behaviour you described is known. The reason behind that is, for inventory managed materials, all exchange rate differences between goods receipt and invoice receipt are posted into inventory valuation. This follows the moving average price principle in Public Cloud, where inventory reflects the true acquisition cost including currency fluctuation. Because of this, you cannot configure the system to post such differences directly to the P&L for stock materials.

The reason why you cannot change it via SSCUIs/Account determination is because in public cloud,

  • Account determination for Goods receipt/Invoice receipt and price differences is predefined and limited to configuration via SSCUIs.
  • However, foreign currency differences in purchase orders are automatically adjusted into the inventory if the material is stock-managed and not routed through the price difference or exchange rate different accounts.
  • The only time currency differences hit P&L account is when the procurement is for non-stock materials or service consumption postings but not for inventory.

There are a few options to serve as a workaround.

  • First one looks at non-stock procurement. If your requirement is to isolate FX differences in P&L then configure the material as consumption based. This ensures the entire purchase will hit P&L accounts which includes exchange rate variances.
  • Second, keep stock-manage procurement but report separately on exchange rate affects. You can do this through embedded analytics or custom CDS views.

Consider submitting a customer Influence Request for public cloud to allow routing FX differences to P&L.

Consult the below references for more details.

Inventory Balance Sheet Valuations (App ID: F3343)

Advanced Foreign Currency Valuation in SAP S/4HANA CLOUD

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Job and Automation Monitoring Insights with SAP Cloud ALM Analytics API
entry.content:
In today’s digital operations landscape, raw data is valuable only when it translates into actionable insights. If you're a Job Monitoring user in SAP Cloud Application Lifecycle Management (SAP Cloud ALM), you're already working with a wealth of data related to execution status, application status, Runtimes, and start delay.

But what if you want a dashboard that displays the KPIs that are more important for your business, other than the pre-provided KPIs in Job and Automation Monitoring?

The answer lies in the SAP Cloud ALM Analytics API—a powerful interface designed to give you direct, structured access to the metrics that matter most for Job and Automation Monitoring.

Why the SAP Cloud ALM Analytics API for Job Monitoring?

The Analytics API is a customer-facing interface that empowers you to retrieve Job and Automation Monitoring data directly, bypassing the limitations of predefined dashboards.

Key Benefits for Job Monitoring Users:

  • Centralized Access: You can view all your job-related analytics (execution stats, errors, warnings) in one unified interface.
  • Seamless Integration: Connect effortlessly with tools like Grafana and other external tools.
  • Flexible Data Consumption: Build custom dashboards or run tailored analytics via any OData-compatible tool.
  • Comprehensive Metrics & Dimensions: Analyze jobs using runTime, execution status, job types, and more.

Whether you're tracking SLAs, identifying performance bottlenecks, or evaluating job failure trends, the API gives you full control over your monitoring insights.

Core Concepts for Job Monitoring Analytics

The Analytics API provides structured, context-rich access to your job monitoring data using the following key elements:

Providers

  • Define the data source—for Job Monitoring, use: DP_JOB_MONITORING

Metrics (Measures)

Metric

Description

runTime

Total runtime of job executions during the selected period.

averageRunTime

Average runtime of completed job executions.

executions

Total number of jobs started.

success

Jobs that completed successfully (green status).

warning

Jobs completed with warnings (yellow status).

aborted

Jobs that were aborted or failed (red status).

applicationWarning

Application-level warning in job execution.

applicationError

Application-level error during job execution.

These metrics let you go beyond surface-level insights and dive deep into operational KPIs for job performance.

Dimensions (Attributes)

Dimension

Description

serviceId

Unique identifier for the monitored service.

serviceName

Name of the monitored service.

jobId

Unique job identifier.

jobName

Name of the monitored job.

jobType

Technical type of the job.

jobTypeLabel

Human-readable label for the job type.

serviceType

Technical type of the monitored service.

These dimensions let you filter, group, and drill down into data across job types, services, or execution IDs.

Output Formats & Visualization

The API supports multiple output formats tailored to different analytical needs:

Below, we have provided an example of a Grafana dashboard with various types of visualizations for Job and Automation Monitoring.

  • Series: Time-based or categorical trends – ideal for charting job execution over time.

  • Table: Structured tabular data aligned with dimensions – great for detailed views.

  • Bar Graph: Categorical group-based comparisons (e.g., job success rate by type).

  • There are other visualizations available, like Pie Chart, Heat Map, Histogram etc.

Flexible Time Resolutions for Monitoring

Different monitoring needs require different time views. The API supports:

  • Period (P): Aggregated single value for a selected duration (e.g., total executions in 7 days).
  • Raw (R): One-minute intervals – ideal for real-time or near real-time dashboards.
  • Minutes (1, 5, 15, 30), Hourly (H), Daily (D): Scalable resolutions for both operational and strategic reporting.

NEW: Period Resolution (P)
Get summarized insights without needing full-time series data. Example:
"What is the total max averageRunTime for a particular duration?" → one value, fast response.

Here, it shows the single point for the total averageRunTime from 7th April to 9th April.

Beyond Standard Dashboards

SAP provides default dashboards for Job Monitoring, focusing on:

  • Start Delay
  • Runtime
  • Application Status
  • Execution Status

However, the Analytics API allows you to:

  • Build custom dashboards to track KPIs specific to your operations.
  • Integrate with third-party BI tools like Tableau, Power BI, or Grafana.
  • Generate advanced insights for capacity planning, SLA monitoring, root cause analysis, and more.

Example Use Cases for Job Monitoring

Here’s how real users apply the API in Job and Automation Monitoring:

Use Case

Example

SLA Breach

       Monitor averageRunTime in last 24 hours to get insights.

Failure Trends

       Analyze weekly aborted or applicationError counts by job type.

Job Volume Reporting

       Daily summary of executions across all services.

Job-Type Efficiency

       Compare averageRunTime across different jobTypeLabels.

 

Business Value for Job Monitoring Teams

Using the SAP Cloud ALM Analytics API, Job Monitoring teams can:

  • Break free from rigid dashboards.
    Create KPIs that reflect your business processes and performance metrics.
  • Unlock tailored insights.
    Focus on what matters most—like success execution, aborted execution, Application warnings, Application error.
  • Connect to enterprise BI tools.
    Integrate SAP Cloud ALM monitoring data into your existing analytics infrastructure.
  • Enable low-code analytics.
    Use no-code or low-code tools to visualize, automate, and share insights organization-wide.

Useful Links

  • SAP Cloud ALM Analytics API
  • Expert portal

entry.title: Re: S4HPC Allergen information
entry.content:
Hello @Asriramoju 

Thank you for your question.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud does not have the exact equivalent of the on-premise WM Industry Add-On functionality for allergen-aware put-away that checks adjacent storage bins to enforce storage restrictions by allergen class during put-away.

However, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides capabilities for managing allergen information at the product and material level. This supports product compliance and handling but does not extend to physical warehouse put-away restrictions based on allergen segregation in storage bins as described in the on-premise EWM Add-On.

Consider the workarounds below:

  • First is to separate storage type by defining dedicated storage types, areas and sections. You can use putaway control indicators or storage type search sequence to ensure allergens are stored only in designated areas.
  • Secondly, use segmentation to differentiate allergen batches and ensure they are handled in separate bin groups.
  • Finally, consider custom validation using BTP side-by-side extension to validate putaway tasks before confirmation. Please note, this requires custom logic outside the public cloud standard.

If your customer requires this functionality, a hybrid model or consulting SAP for cloud-compatible add-ons/custom solutions might be necessary.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to enable the Event Mesh from the BTP Integration Suite with S/4 Hana Public Cloud
entry.content:
As mentioned: once you have completed the initial steps and have the Service Key available, you can follow this documentation.    

With the service key you need to create a new Communication Arrangement in S/4 with the scenario ID SAP_COM_0092.

In short:

  1. BTP: Activate Event Mesh capability inside SAP Integration Suite
  2. BTP: Create service instance of plan messaging-client
  3. BTP: Create service-key/service-binding for the instance
  4. S/4: Create new Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0092 and provide service-key
  5. S/4: Assign events to newly created channel
  6. BTP: Create queue and subscribe topics exposed by S/4
  7. S/4: Create event

With that S/4 will be able to send events to Event Mesh. Finally repeat steps 1-3 and create an iFlow with AMQP adapter and use the credentials from the service-key to connect the consumer side.

entry.title: Re: EXTERNAL JOIN when using temporary tables
entry.content:
Hello Don, thank you for the detailed feedback.

As mentioned before, the links never disappeared, even though the report contains temporary tables. The TableLinks collection holds all links as expected at all times. I also tried removing and restoring the links at runtime, but the result is the same. As soon as any temporary table is involved, Crystal Reports generates external joins instead of inner/outer joins.

Anyway, I found a solution that isn't very elegant, but it works. I create a view on top of the temporary table at runtime. Crystal Reports treats this as a persistent table, and the SQL query is created with inner/outer joins as expected.

entry.title: Re: There is already a handling unit * posted for GR with...
entry.content:
Go to SMQ2 in ERP, find the LUW from EWM for this delivery. Display the error text. You should still see the HU conflict message unless you have already cleaned up the HU in ERP.

If you have already deleted/archived the old HU in ERP, make sure it is really gone from HUMO and not assigned to any historical document. If you can’t delete it (archiving restrictions), the only safe fix is to repack in EWM into a different HU number and re‑trigger the GI message. Even though EWM shows GI posted, you can still use /SCWM/PRDO to unpack/repack into a new HU. Then use /SCWM/POST to re‑post the GI. This will create a new queue to ERP.

“Cancel not allowed” in ERP" is coming from SD because a billing document exists for the delivery. If the billing document is not yet posted to accounting and can be cancelled, reverse it via VF11, then reverse the GI in VL09. If the billing document is already posted and cannot be cancelled, you cannot reverse the GI in ERP.  You must instead fix the posting from EWM so that ERP receives a successful GI message.

If EWM says GI posted but ERP does not, you have a status mismatch. To fix:

Option 1: Cancel GI in EWM (/SCWM/POST → Reverse GI), repack into a new HU, then post GI again so the new queue posts cleanly in ERP.

Option 2: If reversal in EWM is blocked because ERP never posted GI, you can use the queue reset approach. In SMQ1 (EWM outbound), delete the bad LUW. Manually post the GI in ERP (VL02N/VL06O) after fixing the HU number. Then manually set the delivery to completed in EWM (via PPF action or status update).

Finally, and importantly, separate HU number ranges between EWM and ERP so old ERP HUs can never be reused in EWM. Train users not to attempt GI reversal in ERP for EWM‑managed deliveries — always reverse in EWM first.

entry.title: Re: Logic Cash Collection Tracker in Account Receivable O...
entry.content:
Hi @12345678901 

  1. The target amount in the Cash Collection Tracker is derived from the sum of all open invoices due from previous periods, invoices posted in previous periods but due in the selected period and new invoices both posted and due within the selected period. This total due receivables amount forms the collection target for the period you are analyzing.
  2. In regard to calculation of Actual and Target Figures in the Bar Chart:
  • Target figure represents the total receivables due for the selected period, as described above.
  • On the other hand, actual figure Reflects the amount collected during the selected period. It is the sum of payments received against these due invoices within the timeframe.

The bar chart visually compares the actual collections against the target to show collection performance and outstanding amounts.

For deeper technical details, SAP Note 3585697 explains field calculations and logic in the Cash Collection Tracker app.

Consult the references below for more details.

Analyzing the SAP Collections Management Process – Collection Manager

3474257 - Cash Collection Tracker - Accounts Receivable App ID F2925

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Unable to change PO subcontracting material component...
entry.content:
For information, those component lines are not stored in the same PO item table; they’re managed via the subcontracting BOM explosion logic and the function module ME_COMPONENTS_MAINTAIN. The BAPI doesn’t call that FM for changes, so even if you fill POCOMPONENTS and POCOMPONENTSX, the data is ignored, and the original values are returned.

As you might be knowing, subcontracting components are stored in EKPO/EKET for the main item and RESB for the exploded components. In ME22N, when you change the batch in the Components tab, the screen logic calls ME_COMPONENTS_MAINTAIN to update the RESB entry. BAPI_PO_CHANGE does not trigger this component‑maintenance logic; it only processes the main PO item structures. As a result, your changes to POCOMPONENTS are never applied.

You can try with ME_COMPONENTS_MAINTAIN. If you are in ECC or S/4HANA on‑premise/Private Cloud, you can:

  • Read the existing component data with ME_READ_COMPONENTS.
  • Modify the batch field (CHARG) in the component structure.
  • Call ME_COMPONENTS_MAINTAIN to update it.
  • Then call ME_PO_COMMIT or BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT.

This is essentially what ME22N does behind the scenes.

entry.title: Re: How to show CGST, SGST and IGST separately in Adobe F...
entry.content:
Hello @Sanjay_BS1 

You don’t need backend logic to split GST. The standard billing form SDBIL_CI_STANDARD_IN already receives the pricing components of the billing document, including tax conditions. You can display CGST / SGST / IGST separately by modifying the form layout and reading the relevant tax condition types from the pricing elements node.

Suggested approach for Public Cloud

Create a personalised copy of the form

Update Form Templates → copy SDBIL_CI_STANDARD_IN to YY1_… and download it for Adobe LiveCycle editing.

Assign your customised template via Output Parameter Determination (Billing Document) for country :-IN.

Bind CGST/SGST/IGST amounts in the template

Within Adobe, in the context of the template, utilise the Pricing Elements node condition-by-condition.

Sum amounts by condition type used for India GST in your pricing process for CGST, SGST, and IGST condition types

Display three totals (CGST, SGST, IGST) and keep the cumulative GST if needed.

Review your specific condition types in the pricing through Manage Prices, excluding Sales / Set Pricing minus Sales. Note that names may vary by project, so make sure you use the condition types that your tenant is using.

(Optional) Expose additional fields

If a field you need isn’t available in the form context, add it through Data Source Extensions and then rebind it in the template.

No BAdI or backend split is necessary in Public Cloud; all data is retrieved through the form’s data source, and you manage the presentation within the template.

You can make a Quick test

Manage Billing Documents → Output Items → Preview.

Validate item splits and header totals.

SAP useful References for public use

  • SAP Help – Maintain Form Templates (create/copy/edit form templates):
  • SAP Help – Output Parameter Determination (assign template for Billing Documents):
  • SAP Help – Data Source Extensions (expose extra fields to form context):
  • SAP Help – India (IN) – GST in Sales (overview of GST in SD pricing & tax)

Let me know if you need further information

With kind regards

Chuma

I upgraded VS from 2019 to 2022, CRforVS from 13.0.26 to 13.0.38, using the .exe right click run as administrator

References in the project point to what seems the correct location for me (\\..\Win64_x64\dotnet\...).
The version in there is 13.0.38.5404 stamped 2025-05-27.

The application builds fine using debug/release x64. Test on that machine with CR works as well.

On target machines though, after uninstalling CRRuntime 13.0.26 and installing CRRuntime 13.0.38, we get "type initializer for CrystalDecisions.Shared.SharedUtils threw an exception".

If I uninstall 13.0.38 again, and re-install 13.0.26 - strange enough - it works fine.
I can do this over and over again; 13.0.26 will work, while 13.0.38 will throw the exceptions.

Things I tried:
- registering the DLLs manually in the development machine
- removing CRViewer control and replace it again from (new) toolbox
- re-installing VCRedist 15-22 .14
all to no avail.

Please advise on how to find and preferrably solve that problem.

Thanks,
André

entry.title: ‌🎩‌The Magic of Attributes in SAP IAS: Default vs Enrich Assertion
entry.content:
✨🪄 Revellio 🪄✨

                                                                                                      🌟🔮🧙‍♀️🪄✨🧝‍♂️🌟

                                                        “ Unveiling the secrets of Identity Federation, one step at a time…”

✨🧙‍♂️ Unlocking SAP IAS Attribute Magic: Default vs Enrich Secrets Revealed 🎩

About Me

Hare Krishna 🙏 I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

🌟Introduction

When integrating SAP SaaS products on BTP, managing user attributes becomes a big challenge. Every app expects something slightly different—from hardcoded values to custom claim names. Without IAS, you'd have to tame these discrepancies in every corporate IdP or app individually, which isn't sustainable.

🔑IAS centralizes this with:

  1. 🟦 Default Attributes

  2. 🟩 Enrich Assertion Attributes

  3. ⚙️Identity Federation controls which method is applied

📘Concepts: When Which Mechanism Applies

Default vs. Enrich Assertion Attributes

SAP IAS provides two methods to control how attributes are sent to applications:

1. 🟦 Default Attributes

  • Configured at the application level inside IAS.

  • Can be static (hardcoded), pulled from IAS user store, or derived.

  • ✅Used when Identity Federation is enabled.

2. 🟩 Enrich Assertion Attributes

  • Configured in the corporate IdP connection inside IAS.

  • Uses values from the upstream IdP, with transformation before sending to apps.

  • ✅Used when Identity Federation is disabled.
    (📄 Official Doc)

🔄Identity Federation in IAS

Identity Federation decides whether IAS acts as the authoritative IdP 🆔 or a proxy 🔀:

  • Federation Enabled

    • IAS processes 🟦 Default Attributes.

    • Useful even when using corporate IdP—IAS can inject hardcoded values like Groups = sac.

  • Federation Disabled

    • IAS functions as a pass-through proxy.

    • Only 🟩 Enrich Assertion Attributes are active, customizing only based on the upstream IdP data.
      (📄 Reference)

💡This flexibility ensures SAP SaaS tools always receive what they expect—without demanding changes in your corporate IdP or each app.

🌟How IAS Helps Customers

Setting up SSO for SAP SaaS apps can be tricky—each service has its own attribute requirements. Without IAS, you’d constantly tweak your corporate IdP or each app.

With Default and Enrich Assertion Attributes, IAS provides a centralized layer to standardize attributes once and reuse across apps.

🔑Real-World Scenarios(few examples)

SAP ServiceRequiredHow IAS helps
Datasphere / SAC 📊Groups = sacA retail company can inject this via Default Attribute to authorize analysts without changing Azure AD groups.
Signavio 🟧signavio_groupsA manufacturing firm maps workspace groups via Enrich Assertion when federation is off, or as Default Attribute when federation is on—no IdP restructuring needed.
Kyma Runtime 🌀Groups as groupsA tech startup transforms incoming Group claims from Okta to groups for app provisioning without any code changes.
SAP BTP Services 🔷firstname, lastname, emailA logistics company ensures consistent user attributes from IAS or upstream IdP for automated user provisioning.

💡Customer Value

  • Less Customization: Corporate IdPs remain clean; no per-app hacks.

  • Faster Rollouts: Onboard new SAP tools quickly.

  • Compliance & Governance: Centralized attribute control improves auditability.

  • Flexibility: Hardcode, map, or enrich attributes depending on SaaS needs—without breaking federation.

Whether it’s Datasphere, Signavio, or Kyma, IAS ensures your SSO setup just works, letting IT teams focus on business instead of identity headaches.

⚙️Configuring Attributes in IAS — Step-by-Step

Here’s how to set up each mechanism using the IAS Admin Console 🖥️:

1. 🟦 Configure Default Attributes (for Federation Enabled)

  • Navigate to IAS Admin Console → Applications.

  • Select your application (e.g., 📊 Datasphere).

  • Go to Trust → Assertion Attributes / Default Attributes.

  • Add Default Attribute:

    • Example: Groups = sac (hardcoded value)

    • Or map values: ${user.firstName}, ${user.company}

  • 💾Save and exit.
    (📄 Doc)

2. 🟩 Configure Enrich Assertion Attributes (for Federation Disabled)

  • Go to IAS Admin Console → Identity Providers → Corporate Identity Providers.

  • Select your corporate IdP (e.g., Microsoft Entra ID logo 🔵).

  • Open the Assertion Enrichment tab.

  • Add mapping rules:

    • Example: ${user.email} → emailAddress

    • Example: ${customAttribute1} → employeeNumber

  • 💾Save the configuration.
    (📄 Doc)

3. 🧪 Test and Validate

  • Use IAS’s Test tool 🧰 or a SAML tracer 🔍.

  • Confirm:

    • 🟦 Default Attributes appear with Federation Enabled.

    • 🟩 Enrich mappings appear with Federation Disabled.

📸Real-Life Example (Screenshot Placeholder) 

🏗️ Architecture: IAS as Proxy (OIDC ↔ SAML)

 BTP Application (BAS)
          │  (OIDC)
          ▼
   ┌──────────────────────────────┐
   │           SAP IAS            │
   │  ┌────────────────────────┐  │
   │  │   Application Side     │◄─┼─ Identity Federation Enabled
   │  │   (Default Attributes) │  │
   │  └────────────────────────┘  │
   │                              │
   │  ┌────────────────────────┐  │
   │  │ Corporate IdP Side     │◄─┼─ Identity Federation Disabled
   │  │ (Enrich Assertion Attr)│  │
   │  └────────────────────────┘  │
   └──────────────────────────────┘
          │  (SAML)
          ▼
   Corporate Identity Provider

Step-by-Step Explanation for Different Scenarios

Scenario 1: Enhancement of attributes coming from Identity provider.

Without Identity Federation Enabled

Users in IAS (user which we will use don't exist in IAS)

Identity fedration is disabled

And Enrich assertion attributes are not set. Expectation is - IAS should direct the Attributes coming from IDP to SAP BTP application(BAS in our scenario)

Perform Login Process to generate Assertion(from IDP) and JWT token(from IAS).

Enter Corporate IDP credentials -  User: idpuser@test.com

Login Successful to SAP BTP Application

In SAML assertion from IDP we can see - Groups are coming as part of SAML assertion.

When checked in Troubleshooting logs in IAS - We can see the same attributes.

Now in Corporate IDP - Enrich assertion attributes - to send Groups as Hogwarts_Groups to BTP application. In this scenario - Groups will be sent packaged as Hogwarts_Groups to Application which can be used for specific scenarios.

When we login - we can check in troubleshooting logs of IAS that expected attributes are sent.

Now when we enable Identity Fedration

Enable identity fedration - in corporate IDP -> identity fedration.

Now Enrich assertion attributes in Corporate IDP don't work - we will need to use another functionality called Default attributes in Applications in IAS. In below screenshot we can see that it didn't send any IDP attributes.

Now Setup Default attributes in IAS application as shown in below screenshot - make sure you select corporate IDP in drop down menu to send the attributes from Corporate IDP

Perform login to Application again

Now expected attributes are received by BTP application

Scenario 2: Sending Hardcoded values to Applications using IAS

When Identity Fedration is disabled

Perform it in Corporate IDP -> Enrich assertion attributes

Post successful login - we can check Hard coded values are sent to Application

Identity fedration enabled

IAS application -> Default Attributes -> Set Attrubtes

Post successful login - we can check that Hard coded values are sent to BTP application

🚀Why It Matters

  • 🔗Centralization: Handle diverse SAP SaaS attribute needs from one place.

  • 📈Scalability: Onboard new services without remapping custom attributes everywhere.

  • 🛠️ Maintainability: If tools change, update once in IAS—not in 5 different places.

Whether you’re setting up Datasphere 📊, Signavio 🟧, Kyma 🌀, or other BTP tools, IAS gives you a clean, unified way to tailor attributes—without touching your corporate IdP or apps.

                                                     ✨🦌🪄 Expecto Patronum 🪄🦌✨

                                                                                                              🌟🔮🧙‍♂️✨🧝‍♀️🌟
                                                                                    — may your SAP magic always shine bright!

entry.title: Re: This app is not enabled for key user adaptation
entry.content:
Hello @RaghavanKathamuthu 

Thanks for the update.

Two quick clarifications and a checklist to unblock you:

Key user extensibility is not the same as “Adapt UI (RTA)”. While many apps support Custom Fields & Logic (CFL), they do not support RTA. This is why you receive the message, "This app is not enabled for key user adaptation."

What you should do

Within CFL, set up your field in the right QM business context, select the Defect List/Object Page under UIs and Reports, and publish. The field will then appear under Extension Fields, with no need for RTA.

If visible but not editable: switch to Edit mode, verify that the status/page is changeable, ensure the field is not set to Read Only in CFL, and check that your role permits modifications. Clear cache and retest.

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: SAP SuccessFactors and Entra Integration - Issue
entry.content:
Hi experts,

I'm experiencing two different writeback errors when provisioning from Azure AD to SuccessFactors. Most users provision successfully, but a few are failing with these specific errors. Any guidance would be appreciated!

Issue 1: Regulatory Right to be Removed

An entry cannot not be provisioned in this target: SuccessFactors. The entry is 1xx92. The reason the entry cannot be provisioned is internal to that application. An example of why an entry cannot be provisioned is a user with a given public identifier, such as an email address, having previously exercised a regulatory right to be removed from the application.

Issue 2: Missing Required Properties

Error code: SuccessFactorsWritebackRequiredPropertiesMissing
Error message: Please add required properties in payload. Required property status is missing. You can check which properties are required for an entity in Admin Center > OData API Data Dictionary or the entity metadata. with the index 0

Thanks in advance for your help!

entry.title: Día 1 - Digital Drive: Desatando el Poder de SAP Cloud ALM para la Transformación Empresarial
entry.content:
Para aquellos que no tuvieron la oportunidad de asistir a nuestros eventos presenciales, estamos encantados de invitarles a nuestro próximo Digital Drive: Unleashing SAP Cloud ALM for Business Transformation MCLAC en formato webinar, que se llevará a cabo el 10 y 11 de septiembre. Durante estos dos días, ofreceremos sesiones de una duración de 1 hora y 30 minutos cada una, comenzando a las 15h30 (BRT).

Registrese: [Webinar] Digital Drive: Unleashing SAP Cloud ALM for Business Transformation - MCLAC (Día 1 - Implementation)

Este evento está diseñado especialmente para proporcionar una visión integral sobre la gestión del ciclo de vida de las aplicaciones (ALM) y ofrecer las últimas novedades y tendencias en el campo. Estas sesiones son una oportunidad única para aprender de expertos y optimizar el uso de soluciones ALM en su organización.

Detalles del Evento:

  • Día 1 - Implementación: 10 de Septiembre
  • Día 2 - Operaciones: 11 de Septiembre
  • Duración de cada sesión: 1 hora y 30 minutos
  • Hora de inicio: 15h30 (BRT)

Requisitos previos:

Le solicitamos que complete los siguientes pasos antes de participar en el evento:

  1. Realice el proceso de activación de su tenant. Acceda al enlace para activar su SAP Cloud ALM (en caso de que aún no haya sido aprovisionado): https://me.sap.com/systemsprovisioning/provisioning.
  2. Cómo Solicitar SAP Cloud ALM en SAP for Me: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=axFjM01ZnU0.
  3. Recuerde el ID de usuario y la contraseña que se utilizaron para reclamar el tenant de SAP Cloud ALM y también para el cockpit del BTP.
  4. Enlace para acceder al cockpit del BTP: https://account.hana.ondemand.com/#/home/welcome.
  5. Verifique el correo electrónico de notification@sap.com para el enlace de acceso a su SAP Cloud ALM y próximos pasos.

Enlace para acceder a Configuración y Administración para SAP Cloud ALM - Configuración de la Fundación: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/setup-administration/enabling-api.
